title: Who won the most prize money at the 2024 Tour de France?
content:
Cyclist
Who won the most prize money at the 2024 Tour de France?

The Tour de France 2024 has finally rounded out with Tadej Pogačar becoming the first rider in 26 years to do the Giro-Tour double. With this victory, Pogačar becomes the youngest rider to ever win three Tours de France.

Before the race, we broke down all the figures behind the Tour de France’s €2.282 million prize pot, with insight into how much each classification provides. Now it’s all been divvied out, we delve into the Tour’s big money questions. How much did Tadej Pogačar win at the Tour de France? Which teams brought home big bucks despite a small budget? And, who flopped despite having a €50 million team budget?

Also, bear in mind that prize money is usually split among the whole team, both riders and staff.

Tadej Pogačar secures an estimated total of €650,000

There are no prizes for guessing that Tadej Pogačar picked up the most prize money at the 2024 Tour de France. His haul is headlined by the €500,000 cheque given for the overall win. This is equivalent to 70,000 Big Macs, 170 bottles of Chateau Pétrus, the world’s most expensive wine or 31 full Colnago V4Rs bikes.

On his way to overall glory, Pogačar picked up some neat bonuses. The 25-year-old won €66,000 for his six stage wins, plus the daily amounts awarded for wearing the yellow jersey (€9,000 throughout the race), and a healthy five-figure tally for his stage placings. In total, he earned the team approximately €650,000 by our estimations. This is the most he has ever earned at a single Tour de France.

The second most lucrative rider at the Tour in terms of prize money is Visma-Lease a Bike’s Jonas Vingegaard. The Dane clocked up an estimated total of around €250,000, including the €200,000 earned for finishing as the runner-up.

The best young rider, Remco Evenepoel, finished in third place overall at the 2024 Tour de France. In total, he comes out as the third highest prize money scorer at the 2024 race. We estimate that Evenepoel’s winnings, including €100,000 for finishing on the podium, round out to approximately €170,000.

Biniam Girmay, the green jersey winner, clocked up a prize money haul of somewhere around €85,000-€90,000. He is the fourth biggest earner from the Tour.

UAE Team Emirates on top alongside GC giants

To no one’s surprise, UAE Team Emirates take home the biggest cheque from this Tour de France. In total, Pogačar’s team raked in €806,810. The team, who filled three spots in the top ten of GC, also took home the team classification prize worth €50,000, plus Pogačar’s six stage wins. In total, UAE Team Emirates won 35.3% of the total prize money on offer at this year’s Tour. For context, this is a larger prize pool than Jumbo-Visma’s €779,750 won during their barnstorming 2022 Tour.

The rest of the prize money podium comprises the rest of the GC podium teams. Visma-Lease a Bike took home the second largest amount of prize money on €356,220 – 44% of UAE’s total winnings. Soudal-QuickStep received €248,860, including the €20,000 awarded for Evenepoel’s white jersey victory.

Intermarché-Wanty were the Tour’s overachievers, finishing in fourth place in the team prize money standings. With a total prize pot of €111,760, the Belgian team were the highest non-GC team on the list. This is mainly due to Girmay’s green jersey win and his three stage wins. However, Mike Teunissen’s €3,000 prize for being the best teammate of the second week can also be added into the mix.

EF Education-EasyPost salvaged their Tour de France balance sheet in the final week of the race. Richard Carapaz’s stage win in SuperDévoluy, his late raid on the polka dot jersey and his super combative prize brought the American team’s total to a healthy €90,210. They finished in a respectable fifth place in the prize money standings.

Full Tour de France 2024 prize money standings

  1. UAE Team Emirates (€806,810)
  2. Visma-Lease a Bike (€356,220)
  3. Soudal-QuickStep (€248,860)
  4. Intermarché-Wanty (€111,760)
  5. EF Education-EasyPost (€90,210)
  6. Alpecin-Deceunick (€77,520)
  7. Ineos Grenadiers (€65,780)
  8. Uno-X Mobility (€60,170)
  9. Movistar Team (€54,060)
  10. TotalEnergies (€50,300)
  11. Lidl-Trek (€41,980)
  12. Jayco-AlUla (€37,740)
  13. Lotto-Dstny (€37,170)
  14. Cofidis (€34,770)
  15. DSM-Firmenich-PostNL (€34,200)
  16. Israel-Premier Tech (€33,130)
  17. Groupama-FDJ (€31,720)

  19. Arkéa-B&B Hotels (€23,820)
  20. Astana-Qazaqstan (€20,690)
  21. Decathlon-AG2R La Mondiale (€18,260)
  22. Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe (€16,710)

Decathlon-AG2R disappoint and Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe trail

Looking through the list, Uno X punched above their weight. Jonas Abrahamsen will also feel hard done by having missed out on the €20,000 cheque offered to the most combative rider to Carapaz.

TotalEnergies – another UCI ProTeam – ended up in the top half of the rankings with €50,300, helped by Anthony Turgis’s stage win on Stage 9, Mattéo Vercher’s close call on Stage 18 and Steff Cras’s 16th place in GC.

Towards the lower end of the scale, three WorldTour teams hold the bottom three places.

Despite Mark Cavendish’s stage win Astana Qazaqstan received the third smallest prize money sum, with €20,690. Just over half of this came from Cav. With Chinese firm XDS’s backing in the new year, the team will be hoping to improve greatly in Tours to come.

Decathlon-AG2R underwhelmed in this Tour de France. The French squad signed off with a cheque of just €18,260 as a result, the second-lowest amount. This is a big contrast to the team’s top five position in the 2024 UCI Rankings coming into the race.

Rounding out the teams is Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe. Much was expected of Ralf Denk‘s squad after an active transfer market and a bold rebrand ahead of the Tour. Instead, the team failed to win any stages and lost any chance of finishing in the top 15 of GC. In return, the German team secured a prize pot of just €16,710.

Prize money and team budget comparison

In order to unravel who the real winners and losers were based on the team’s financial means, we divided the prize money won at the Tour de France by the team’s budget. According to leaked information, team budgets vary from the €55 million marker (UAE Team Emirates) to €16 million (Intermarché-Wanty). This ranking should give a fair ranking of who had the best Tour de France regardless of fiscal constraint.

A necessary caveat is that only WorldTour team budgets were calculated through the leaked budget estimations. Therefore, TotalEnergies, Lotto-Dstny, Uno-X and Israel-Premier Tech do not feature in this ranking. All these teams, however, performed better than some big budget WorldTour outfits.

Full ranking of prize money divided by team budget

  1. UAE Team Emirates
  2. Soudal-Quickstep
  3. Intermarché-Wanty
  4. Visma-Lease a Bike
  5. EF Education-EasyPost
  6. Alpecin-Deceuninck
  7. Movistar Team
  8. Cofidis
  9. Jayco-AlUla
  10. DSM-Firmenich-PostNL
  11. Arkéa-B&B Hotels
  12. Groupama-FDJ
  13. Lidl-Trek
  14. Ineos Grenadiers
  15. Bahrain Victorious
  16. Astana-Qazaqstan
  17. Decathlon-AG2R La Mondiale
  18. Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe

Big budgets rewarded, tighter teams overperformed

UAE Team Emirates sit at the top of the list, and it’s to be expected given that the team has the biggest budget in the sport. Its yearly expenditure of around €55 million is reflected in the high calibre of riders. Soudal-QuickStep and Visma-Lease a Bike also showed their deep pockets.

Intermarché-Wanty are the WorldTour team with the smallest budget in the top-tier of professional cycling. For them to sit within the top three of financial performers is very impressive. EF also have a budget within the lower quartile of the WorldTour, making this Tour de France a very lucrative three weeks of racing.

Ineos, Bahrain and (yet again) Red Bull outplayed

On the other end of the spectrum, Lidl-Trek disappointed despite a big budget increase courtesy of the German supermarket’s financial injection last year. The team of Mads Pedersen and Giulio Ciccone finished the Tour outside of the top ten in GC and without a stage win for the first time since 2019.

Financial underperformers include Ineos Grenadiers, who have a budget of around €50 million, and Bahrain Victorious who have the sixth biggest budget in the WorldTour. Ineos also missed out on key objectives including the top five in GC, the white jersey and even a stage win. Despite the big budget, they stick out like a sore thumb on this list even if the former Tour-winning squad slotted into seventh in the prize money standings.

Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe continue their poor Tour in these rankings. At the beginning of the season, Bora boasted the seventh largest budget in the WorldTour. Whether the Red Bull money has tricked down into the team just yet is unknown. If the budget is bigger as a result of this, their last place will only be amplified.
